poem:
**Sweet Potato Meditation**

In the earthy quiet  
of afternoon kitchens,  
I ponder sweet potatoes,  
their jackets dusted with soil  
like soft-worn secrets.  
Roasted whole, their warmth  
rises on tending hands,  
this bulbous treasure morphs,  
baked and dressed in slaw and cream,  
a modest dish,  
a gentle measure of earthy pleasure.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Like a baked potato, made salad-y’: Alice Zaslavsky’s sweet potato jackets with sour cream and slaw When shopping for sweet potatoes, don’t be scared of soil! A bit of dirt never goes astray, as it acts as a natural barrier to extend shelf life. Select sweet potatoes of a similar size to simplify preparation, particularly if you are planning on roasting them whole like in this recipe, so they all cook through at around the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
